data.title: Dr. Riaz Uddin on LinkedIn: Day-1 (22-11-2023): British Council PAK-UK Mobility Program for faculty…
data.meta_description:
Day-1 (22-11-2023): British Council PAK-UK Mobility Program for faculty and students (Consortium of Six Universities across Pakistan and UK)
It was wonderful… | 10 comments on LinkedIn
data.text:
🔊 🔊 🔊 Call for research proposals for papers or posters presentations at the International Postgraduate Research Conference (IPGRC) 2024 in May 2024. This is a great opportunity for researchers in the field of construction and the built environment. Here are some key points for potential participants: 1. 🏛 Conference Details: The IPGRC 2024 Conference will take place at the University of Salford, UK, from May 28th to May 30th, 2024. Interested participants can find detailed information about the conference, including submission guidelines, at the official link provided: https://lnkd.in/eR4DFSAC. 2. 📅 Key Dates: • Proposal Submission Date: November 1st, 2023 • Acceptance Notification: November 15th, 2023 • Full Paper Submission Date (for conference proceedings): February 15th, 2024 • Paper/Poster Presentation Submission Date: May 15th, 2024 3. 🀄 Sessions: The conference offers a variety of sessions (from Session 1 to Session 11) with different themes. Participants can explore the comprehensive list of sessions at the conference link. 🎏 💌 “Session 1: Collaboration Towards Digital Transformation in Construction”, chaired by me along with Prof. Peter McDermott and Dr. Derek Hales, focuses on collaboration towards digital transformation of the construction sector and the built environment. Session 1 welcomes contributions in this field, and there are specific research topics of interest mentioned via this official link: [https://lnkd.in/eR4DFSAC]. ✍☑✍ Researchers interested in Session 1 can consider contributing to topics such as best practices of collaboration, collaborative working relations, collaborative working platforms, embedded sense of collaboration and its interdependencies in collaboration, and defining collaboration in digitalization projects in construction. 🥉 🎗There are beneficial opportunities to share novel ideas and research methodologies with fellow researchers. Also, take a chance to exchange knowledge and expertise with industry leaders, professionals, and outstanding researchers and interact with PhD research candidates at the University of Salford. It highlights the significance of the research work (especially doctoral level candidates, to submit their proposals) in contributing to the digital transformation of the construction sector. 🌻 🎯 Researchers interested in participating in the IPGRC 2024 Conference and Session 1 are encouraged to submit their proposals by the specified deadlines. 🔯📢This conference offers a valuable platform for researchers to showcase their work and engage with peers in the field of digital transformation in construction. 🙏 Thank you all for your attention and hoping that this conference will be a great success!🌈🌈 #collaborationtowardsdigitaltransformation #acceleratingdigitaltransformation #constructionindustry #thebuiltenvironment #IPGRC 2024:Innovations and Impacts of Research #callforpapers #callforposterpresentations

An online MoU was signed between Ghulam Ishaq Khan Institute of Engineering Sciences and Technology (GIK) in Pakistan and US-based company ArchiWiz. Prof. Dr. Fazal A. Khalid, SI, Rector, GIK Institute, along with Sardar Aminullah Khan, Pro-Rector (A&F), Prof. Syed M. Hassan Zaidi, Pro-Rector (A) and Deans participated in the MoU signing ceremony from the GIK Institute. Mr. Daniyal Feroz, CEO Archiwiz, Dr. Ghanimullah, Dr. Danyal Balki, and Mr. Irfan Qasim attended the online signing ceremony from Archiwiz. The MoU signifies a commitment to mutual collaboration in various domains, including academic exchange, research and development, technology transfer, and innovation. GIK and ArchiWiz were dedicated to fostering joint initiatives to drive technological advancement and growth in their respective fields. Key highlights of the MoU include: Academic Exchange: The MoU emphasizes the exchange of scientific, academic, and technical information, as well as the opportunity for faculty, staff, and students to collaborate on research, teaching, and discussions. Joint Research and Development: Both parties will engage in collaborative research and development activities, focusing on areas of mutual interest, including enhancing Building Information Modelling (BIM) implementation in Pakistan and conducting joint simulations and experiments. Innovation and Startups: The MoU promotes joint initiatives to foster innovation, entrepreneurship, and the startup ecosystem at GIK. It also encourages cooperation on digital twins for medical and engineering applications. This MoU signifies a significant step in bridging international boundaries for academic and research collaboration, aiming to create innovative solutions and promote technological progress. Both institutions are enthusiastic about this partnership's potential and look forward to realizing their shared goals. The MoU is initially set for three years and can be extended or modified by mutual consent. It is seen as a foundation for future joint endeavors and an example of international cooperation in technology and education.

🚀 Exciting News: Embarking on My PhD Journey at NMBU! 🎓 I am thrilled to announce the beginning of an exciting new chapter in my academic journey as I start my PhD at NMBU - Norwegian University of Life Sciences next week. I am truly honored to be part of the research community at NMBU and to work on a project that holds immense potential for the future of architecture and human well-being. My research will revolve around "Daylight Quality Behind the Aperture", and I will be diving into the fascinating world of circadian rhythms, daylight's impact on our health, and the spectral composition of daylight in the built environment. Here are some key aspects of the project: 🌞 Circadian Rhythms: I will explore how the circadian rhythm, which regulates melatonin and serotonin production, is influenced by daylight. 🌈 Spectral Composition: I will investigate how the spectral composition of daylight affects our well-being, particularly the melanopic sensitivity, which differs from our visual sensitivity. 🏢 Daylight in Buildings: My research will consider how architectural elements like windows, glass panes, and internal surfaces influence the quality of daylight inside buildings. 🔍 Research Questions: I'll seek answers to questions like how the spectral transmittance of glass impacts our health, the spatial variance of daylight within a room, and whether building design should respond to these findings. 📅 Project Timeline: My research journey will span several years, involving literature reviews, measurements, methodology development, and dissemination of results, with key milestones marked for publications. 👨🏫 Supervisors: I am fortunate to have guidance from experienced mentors, including Arnkell J. Petersen, Thomas Thiis, and Ingunn Burud, who bring expertise in building physics, indoor climate, and related fields. 📚 Ongoing Learning: My journey will also involve taking relevant courses to expand my knowledge and skills in the field. Please feel free to contact me if you want to discuss daylight, building design and other research topics or have suggestions on literature. I am incredibly excited about this opportunity to contribute to our understanding of how daylight quality impacts our lives and the potential implications for architectural design. I look forward to sharing my progress and insights with all of you along the way. Thank you to my family, friends, and mentors who have supported me on this journey. #PhDJourney #DaylightResearch #NMBU #BuildingDesign #CircadianRhythms #SpectralComposition #newjob

Hello Everyone, Earning a degree from a prestigious institution doesn't automatically ensure the competence of a faculty member or researcher. The true growth of a nation hinges on innovative research and the development of products and solutions that contribute to boosting our GDP. This fact becomes clear when examining the team working on the MOON mission project. https://lnkd.in/dTftvMDs After Ganesh Natarajan (Indian Institute of Technology, Palakkad / Indian Institute of Technology, Guwahati?) submitted his stupid comments to American Institute of Physics against a closed form analytical model, there were instances of his active engagement on LinkedIn, ResearchGate, other social media and involvement in academic politics for his survival! However, it's worth noting that all the reviewers ultimately rejected Ganesh Natarajan and his co-authors (IITians) comments. Consequently, their manuscript will not be published by American Institute of Physics, rendering the reviewers' comments moot for online dissemination. Nevertheless, I am sharing these comments here out of academic interest, with the intention of educating aspiring researchers. This situation highlights the importance of not automatically accepting comments from IIT faculty as the final and definitive word. It underscores the idea that academic credentials or institutional affiliations, even those from high-impact institutions, are not prerequisites to uncover the laws of nature. This serves as a valuable lesson for everyone, including the government funding agencies. I'd like to extend my appreciation to Ganesh Natarajan and their team from various IITs/Indian Institute of Science (IISc) for shedding light on the true essence and knowledge of IIT faculty! These observations further solidify the notion that the reputation of IIT/IISc is primarily upheld by its exceptional students and alumni rather than its faculty members. In line with this discussion, it's worth recalling the sentiments expressed by Dr. jairam ramesh, an erstwhile union minister of Bharat, in the past as seen in NDTV (NDTVIndia) https://lnkd.in/duc-Tu_H Indian Institute of Technology, Madras Indian Institute of Technology, Palakkad Indian Institute of Technology Gandhinagar Indian Institute of Technology, Delhi Indian Institute of Technology, Guwahati Indian Institute of Technology, Bombay Indian Institute of Technology, Ropar Indian Institute of Technology, Roorkee Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur Indian Institute of Technology, Bhilai Indian Institute of Science (IISc) ISRO - Indian Space Research Organization National Aerospace Laboratories, Bangalore DRDO, Ministry of Defence, Govt. of India @Joseph Mathew iisc VR SANAL KUMAR Yash Raj DEKKALA VINAY Narendra Modi

Open Call for Rice University Students: Carbon Hub Annual Meeting | Poster Session & Competition Abstract submission: 26th April!!! Students working on all areas related to the Carbon Hub at Rice University (ranging from engineering, natural and social sciences to architecture and humanities) and particularly on topics related to Energy, Climate, Ecology, and Sustainability, are encouraged to participate in the "Carbon Hub Annual Meeting | Poster Session & Competition”. As a reminder, the Carbon Hub aims to drive a sustainable future built on zero-emission hydrogen and carbon materials with high value use and low environmental footprint. The event will take place on May 6nd from 5pm-6pm at the Rice University - Susanne M. Glasscock School of Continuing Studies . Posters will be judged in the three categories to promote the interdisciplinary paradigm that exists on the Rice campus. We are providing three categories, not to differentiate these topics, but to bring them together. 1. Synthesis - the science (Materials Science and NanoEngineering - Rice University) and engineering (Rice University School of Engineering) of making new sustainable materials or chemistries. 2. Applications - the applied use of new sustainable materials and processes to meet climate challenges (Rice WaTER Institute) (Rice Alliance for Technology and Entrepreneurship). 3. Architecture (Rice Architecture), Social Sciences (Rice University School of Social Sciences), and Humanities (Rice University School of Humanities) - societal, policy, conceptual, or other interdisciplinary topics related to the success of climate initiatives. In addition to the opportunity for networking and discussions with academic and industrial researchers, cash prizes will be awarded to the top posters in each category. The prize amounts are: *1st prize: $1000 *2nd prize: $500 *3rd prize: $250 Submission details: A brief (50-100 word) poster abstract should be submitted by April 26th via this Google forms link https://lnkd.in/gu7wnXMv Participants should prepare and print their posters to bring to the workshop; the poster will be mounted on a 4ft by 3ft poster board. We look forward to seeing you at the workshop and poster session; and please feel free to reach out with any questions. Sincerely, The Carbon Hub Workshop Poster Committee: Juan José Castellón (Architecture) Daniel Cohan (Civil and Environmental Engineering) Daniel J. Preston (Mechanical Engineering) Tom Senftle (Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering) #Competition #Energy #Climate #Ecology #Sustainability #interdisciplinaryresearch #innovation #riceuniversity #carbonhub

Two days ago, a friend and I attended the Professor Adejumo Awojobi Design Competition {PAADC} that held at the University of Lagos Main Auditorium. It is a competition whereby students come up with innovative engineering designs and pitch their innovations with the top 3 winners getting cash rewards. Of the top 5 teams that presented, 2 were from UNILAG, 1 from UNIBEN, 1 from Bayero University and 1 from Covenant University. The first UNILAG team presented and it was quite stellar. Then the UNIBEN team presented and I was really unimpressed. Next was the second UNILAG team and I was embarrassed to be a student of UNILAG myself😩. They were immediately followed by the Covenant University team and they did quite well. P.S: I'm not judging their innovations in any way as they all had excellent innovations to present. I'm only just considering their pitch. To be fair, the media team had their share of blame for all the presentations save for the first UNILAG team that presented as there were several hitches and glitches that could easily put most person's off track. But then...🌚 After the four earlier mentioned teams had presented, there came this young man all the way from Bayero University, Kano. He was the only person from his team of 3 that came - I guess logistics cost must have caused this. Kano too far from Lagos gan ooo 😌 This guy came on stage with every iota of confidence you could imagine and from his first statement, he blew our minds away. Imagine starting off with, "they say water is life, but water killed my sister." Despite the media glitches and the fact that at a point, power went out completely for minutes which led to an abrupt pause in his presentation, man still killed the show. We could not find any bit of error. He had sourced for every information you could ever think of and had well-cooked answers to every question thrown at him by the judges. I do not want to go into details here but at the end, it was obvious he was the winner by far. It was indisputable. He bossed the entire show with a wide margin and at the end, he won the first position. It was all cheers for this "man from Kano." Who would believe that one unknown man, who was already disadvantaged due to location, who most person's wouldn't think of considering, let alone beat students from these prestigious universities would come and snatch the gold prize. But yes, man did it...and with a wide margin at that. ...to be continued in the comments section. #TheISAAC
